message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest Cushing’s syndrome, and the low-dose dexamethasone suppression test confirms it. Bilateral hyperplasia of the zona fasciculata is the most likely cause of Cushing’s syndrome in this patient. The other options are not associated with Cushing’s syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest Cushing’s syndrome, and the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test points to adrenal gland hyperplasia. Among the options, only option C mentions zona fasciculata, which is involved in cortisol production.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings suggest Cushing’s syndrome, which is caused by excess cortisol production. High-dose dexamethasone suppression test shows suppression of ACTH, indicating endogenous production of cortisol. Bilateral hyperplasia of the zona fasciculata is the most common cause of Cushing's syndrome. Benign adenoma of the adrenal medulla causes pheochromocytoma, which is characterized by hypertension and elevated levels of catecholamines. Nodular hypertrophy of the zona reticularis is associated with androgen excess. Unilateral carcinoma of the adrenal cortex can cause hypercortisolism, but it is much less common than bilateral hyperplasia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Cushing’s syndrome, and the elevated cortisol levels confirm it. A high-dose dexamethasone suppression test shows suppression of ACTH, suggesting that the adrenal gland is causing the Cushing’s syndrome. Among the options, only bilateral hyperplasia of the zona fasciculata correlates with the pathology of Cushing's syndrome caused by adrenal gland hyperfunction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest Cushing's syndrome, and the suppression of ACTH after a high-dose dexamethasone test suggests Cushing's disease caused by bilateral hyperplasia of the zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex. The other options are not associated with Cushing's syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical exam findings suggest Cushing’s syndrome. The low-dose dexamethasone suppression test shows that the cortisol production is not sensitive to negative feedback, and the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test confirmed that the ACTH originates from the pituitary gland. This is consistent with bilateral hyperplasia of the zona fasciculata, which is one of the most common causes of Cushing's syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest Cushing syndrome, and the low-dose dexamethasone suppression test suggests primary adrenal gland pathology. The high-dose dexamethasone suppression test shows suppression of ACTH, indicating bilateral hyperplasia of the zona fasciculata, which is the most common cause of Cushing syndrome. Benign adenoma of the adrenal medulla causes pheochromocytoma, not Cushing syndrome. Nodular hypertrophy of the zona reticularis is seen in hyperandrogenism. Unilateral carcinoma of the adrenal cortex is less common than bilateral hyperplasia as a cause of Cushing syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient shows symptoms of Cushing’s syndrome, with elevated cortisol levels and suppressed ACTH levels, suggesting that the cause is adrenal-dependent. Among the options, bilateral hyperplasia of the zona fasciculata is the most likely finding in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest Cushing's syndrome, and the low-dose dexamethasone suppression test confirms it. Elevated cortisol levels indicate that the cause is in the adrenal gland. Bilateral hyperplasia of the zona fasciculata is a common cause of Cushing's syndrome. Adenoma of the adrenal medulla causes Pheochromocytomas, not Cushing's syndrome. Nodular hypertrophy of the zona reticularis doesn't cause Cushing's syndrome. Unilateral carcinoma of the adrenal cortex usually causes Conn's syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings suggest Cushing’s syndrome, which can be caused by adrenal gland hyperplasia. Elevated morning serum cortisol levels and suppressed ACTH levels after dexamethasone suppression tests indicate primary adrenal gland disease, rather than pituitary or hypothalamic disease. Bilateral hyperplasia of the zona fasciculata is a common cause of primary adrenal Cushing’s syndrome.
